title-group.article-title: Dietary ascorbic acid as a means to counter the stress of cypermethrin on the growth of freshwater catfish Heteropneustes fossilis

contrib-group.aff: Department of Zoology, University of Kalyani, India

author-notes.corresp: Anilava Kaviraj, Department of Zoology, University of Kalyani, Kalyani 741235, West Bengal, India. Email: akaviraj@gmail.com

abstract.p: Two months of experiments performed in outdoor vats in a 3 × 3 factorial design to evaluate the effects of three sublethal levels (0.0, 0.3 and 0.5 µg L−1) of cypermethrin on freshwater catfish Heteropneustes fossilis fed with three different levels (0.0, 0.5 and 1.0 g kg−1) of ascorbic acid (AA) in the diet. Even the lower sublethal level (0.3 µg L−1) of cypermethrin produced significant reduction in growth and deposition of protein in the body of H. fossilis. Dietary supplement of AA at 0.5 g kg−1 failed to counter these ill effects of cypermethrin on H. fossilis, but a supplement of 1.0 g kg−1 AA significantly increased the AA reserve in the body of the fish, and the ill effects of cypermethrin on growth were reversed. It was concluded that the catfish H. fossilis required an exogenous supply of AA to counter the stress of cypermethrin.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Although pyrethroids are photodegradable and less persistent in the environment when compared with organophosphates, carbamates and other conventional pesticides, these compounds have undergone several modifications in their structure in recent years to suit field condition, biological activity and pest specificity. Thus, most of the modern pyrethroids are more persistent in the environment and potentially hazardous to a wide variety of nontarget organisms. Cypermethrin is a type II pyrethroid in which insecticidal property has been increased by the addition of a cyano group to its alcohol moiety (Bradberry et al., 2005). It is now one of the most widely used insecticides in the agricultural field, and the natural water bodies receiving runoffs from these fields are frequently exposed to this insecticide. Under laboratory conditions, cypermethrin has been found to be acutely toxic to many fish inhabiting Indian water bodies, such as air breathing catfish Heteropneustes fossilis (96-h lethal concentration 50 (LC50) of 1.25 µg L−1) (Saha and Kaviraj, 2003), Indian major carp Catla catla (LC50 of 4.0 µg L−1) (Tandon et al., 2005), common carp Cyprinus carpio (LC50 of 2.6 µg L−1) (Saha and Kaviraj, 2008) and Indian major carp Labeo rohita (LC50 of 4.0 µg L−1) (Marigoudar et al., 2009).

Cypermethrin is sorbed strongly into the organic sediments of natural water systems (Laskowski, 2002) and provides strong threats to the aquatic animals, particularly to those that are mostly associated with bottom sediments or lays eggs over it (Gonzalez-Doncel et al., 2004). H. fossilis is a bottom-dwelling fish inhabiting swamps and shallow water bodies often within or very close to agricultural fields (Chondar, 1999). Short-term exposure (24–96 h) of H. fossilis to sublethal concentrations of cypermethrin (0.3 and 0.5 µg L−1) revealed stresses, such as hyperglycemia in blood, glycogenolysis in liver and reduction of alkaline and acid phosphatase in blood, liver and kidney of this fish (Saha and Kaviraj, 2009). However, long-term effects of the sublethal concentrations of cypermethrin on this fish, particularly its growth, are not known.

The main objective of this study was to evaluate the effects of long-term exposure (60 days) of sublethal concentrations of cypermethrin on the growth of H. fossilis, and the role of dietary ascorbic acid (AA) to ameliorate the ill effect, if any. AA is a nonenzymatic antioxidant, which is involved in the self-defense mechanisms of the fish. However, many fish cannot synthesize AA de novo and require an exogenous supply for optimum growth and self-defense (Ai et al., 2004). It has been observed that the increase in the tissue reserve of AA through dietary supplement can help the catfish Clarias gariepinus (Datta and Kaviraj, 2003) and H. fossilis (Saha and Kaviraj, 2009) to counter the stress of the pyrethroids deltamethrin and cypermethrin, respectively. Level of dietary AA required for normal growth and counteraction of toxicants varies from fish to fish. Mishra and Mukhopadhyay (1996) observed the best growth of freshwater catfish Clarias batrachus with the supplementation of 0.2 mg of AA per kg diet, while Merchie et al. (1995) observed a much higher requirement of AA (2 g per kg of diet) for optimal growth of C. gariepinus. Datta (Bhattacharya) and Kaviraj (2006) observed that 0.5 g of AA per kg diet was found to be adequate to induce higher growth of the catfish C. gariepinus, while a higher concentration of AA (1.0 g kg−1 diet) was necessary to counteract the effects of chronic exposure of this fish to fenvalerate. The present study was designed to evaluate whether dietary supplement of 0.5 and 1.0 g of AA per kg diet could counteract ill effects, if any, of cypermethrin on the growth of H. fossilis.

sec.title: Test fish and experimental design
sec.p: Fingerlings of H. fossilis (mean length 4.11 ± 0.06 cm and mean weight 2.10 ± 0.06 g) were collected from a local hatchery and were stocked in 50 L glass aquaria containing tap water (pH: 8.23 ± 0.04, free CO2: 5.1 ± 0.3 mg L−1, dissolved oxygen (DO): 5.9 ± 0.2 mg L−1, alkalinity: 70.75 ± 3.77 mg L−1 as CaCO3, hardness: 249.33 ± 11.01 mg L−1 as CaCO3). The fish were acclimatized in this condition for 1 week under a natural photoperiod (12 h) and ambient temperature (25–28°C). The acclimatized fish were then stocked in outdoor experimental vats (diameter 90 cm; average depth 45 cm), each containing approximately 400 L of water. Before stocking, each vat was provided with a 3-cm-thick soil sediment at the bottom and was treated with cow dung at 5000 kg ha−1 (approximately each vat required 100 g cow dung). The vats were then filled with water and kept in this condition for 1 month, in order to grow plankton as natural food for the test fish in adequate quantity. Fifteen acclimatized fish irrespective of the sex were stocked in each conditioned vat. A total of 27 such vats were used in the experiment.

The vats were assorted into three blocks, per Randomized Block Design (Gomez and Gomez, 1984), so that the stocked fish could be reared separately on diets supplemented with three different levels of AA. In each block, nine vats were further assorted into three groups so that each diet group received one of the three concentrations of cypermethrin in three replicates (Table 1). Commercial formulation of cypermethrin (United Phosphorus Ltd, Gujrat, India) having 10% emulsifiable concentrate was used in the present study. A stock solution of 100 mg L−1 of cypermethrin, based on the percentage of active ingredients, was prepared and appropriate aliquots of the stock solution were diluted into the rearing medium to produce the required nominal concentrations. The three cypermethrin concentrations, 0.0, 0.3 and 0.5 µg L−1, used in the present study represent the control, 50% and 75%, respectively, of 96-h LC50 value of aqueous cypermethrin for H. fossilis (Saha and Kaviraj, 2003). In order to compensate the loss of water due to evaporation and precipitation of cypermethrin, 10% of the test medium was renewed every 10 days with a pulsed treatment of cypermethrin at 10% of the initial nominal concentration.

sec.title: Formulation of diet
sec.p: A basal diet was formulated using rice bran (18.43%), wheat flour (18.43%), mustard oil cake (18.43%), fish meal (40.71%), vitamin premix without AA (2.0%) and mineral premix (2.0%) as ingredients. The diets were then supplemented with three different levels of AA to prepare three groups of diet: one with no AA (No AA), the second with a low level (0.5 g kg−1 diet) of AA (Low AA) and the third with a high level (1.0 g kg−1 diet) of AA (High AA). Vitamin C tablets (Celine®; Glaxo, India) were used as the source of AA. Since AA is sensitive to heat and moisture and its potency is lost over long storage, only a week’s ration was prepared at any one time to minimize storage loss of AA. Mean actual levels of AA in a week’s ration have been reported as 0.23 ± 0.08 and 0.45 ± 0.12 g kg−1, respectively, after incorporation of AA at 0.5 and 1.0 g kg−1 diet (Saha and Kaviraj, 2009).

sec.title: Feeding and sampling
sec.p: The fish were fed to satiation twice daily (9.00 to 10.00 h and 16.00 to 17.00 h) during the experiment. As mentioned above, for every 10 days, 10% of the test medium was renewed and the physiochemical parameters of water were checked before renewal of water. The experiment was continued for 60 days.

Daily survey was made on the behavior and mortality of the fish. A few fish were sampled before the start of the experiment to determine the initial length, weight and the initial value of carcass protein. All fish were sampled after 60 days. Length and weight of the sampled fish were taken. Sampled fish were then divided into two groups. Fish of one group were dissected to collect liver and kidney tissues to determine the level of AA in these tissues. Carcass protein was determined from the second group of fish.

sec.title: Analytical methods
sec.p: Growth was determined by percentage increase in length, percentage increase in weight, specific growth rate ((SGR) % per day), feed conversion ratio (FCR) and apparent net protein utilization (ANPU %). These parameters were calculated using standard methods (Steffens, 1989). Level of crude protein ((CP) nitrogen × 6.25) in the diet and in carcass was determined by Kjeldahl method after acid hydrolysis following Association of Official Analytical Chemists procedure (Helrich, 1990). AA in liver and kidney was determined by the method of Nino and Prasad (1980). The physicochemical parameters of water (temperature, pH, DO, free carbon dioxide, alkalinity and hardness) were determined by standard methods (APHA, 1995).

sec.title: Statistical methods
sec.p: All growth data were analyzed by multiple analysis of variance (MANOVA) and test statistics using Wilk’s ƛ̣ and Roy’s largest root (Johnson and Wichern, 2001). In case of the results showing significant interaction between the levels of cypermethrin and dietary AA, single-factor analysis of variance (ANOVA) was conducted to determine significant variation between the levels of cypermethrin for each level of dietary AA followed by the least significant difference test.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: All diets, irrespective of AA supplement, contained 30% CP. Effects of sublethal concentrations of cypermethrin (0.3 and 0.5 µg L−1) on the growth of H. fossilis fed different levels of AA-supplemented diet have been summarized in Tables 2 and 3. The results of the experiments revealed 84–90% survival of the fish in the control group. Survival increased in fish fed AA-supplemented diet. Survival reduced significantly (70%) in fish exposed to high concentration of cypermethrin (0.5 µg L−1) and not supported by dietary AA. There was no significant difference in the survival rate between control and cypermethrin-treated (both low and high) fish supported by dietary AA. Cypermethrin treatment reduced the survival of fish that are not protected by dietary AA supplement (Table 2). Both the levels of cypermethrin (0.3 and 0.5 µg L−1) significantly reduced the growth of H. fossilis fed No AA diet when compared with control (cypermethrin of 0.0 µg L−1 and No AA). Percentage increase in length and weight and SGR reduced, while the FCR increased in these fish as a result of cypermethrin treatment (Table 2). ANPU also showed a significant reduction in cypermethrin-treated fish. Both the levels of dietary AA (low AA and high AA) significantly increased the growth of H. fossilis when compared with control (No AA and without any cypermethrin treatment). Dietary AA also influenced the inhibiting effect of cypermethrin on the growth of H. fossilis. Cypermethrin treatments produced no significant effect on any of the parameters when the fish was fed high AA diet. Level of CP in the carcass and the level of AA in liver and kidney determined at the end of the experiment showed a significant reduction as a result of cypermethrin treatment. Dietary supplement of AA significantly increased the level of AA in both the tissues of control and treated fish. But the fish fed low AA failed to elevate the level of AA in cypermethrin-treated fish close to control, while fish fed with high level of AA showed significantly higher level of AA in cypermethrin-treated fish when compared with the control (Table 3).

caption.p: Growth of Heteropneustes fossilis exposed to cypermethrin under different levels of dietary AA.

fn.p: AA: ascorbic acid; SGR: specific growth rate; FCR: feed conversion ratio; ANPU: apparent net protein utilization.
aSGR = {(ln final wt − ln initial wt)/No. of days} × 100.
bANPU = {(net increase in carcass protein/amount of protein consumed)} × 100.

caption.p: Level of carcass protein and AA in the liver and kidney of Heteropneustes fossilis recorded after 60 days exposure to cypermethrin under different levels of dietary AA.

sec.p: Results of MANOVA carried out with data of all the growth and biochemical parameters showed that cypermethrin and dietary AA had significant interaction. Accordingly, one-way ANOVA was performed for each parameter separately for each level of dietary AA. Results of ANOVA showed that except under high dietary AA, cypermethrin treatment produced significant effect on the growth of H. fossilis fed either No or Low AA in the diet. Water quality parameters recorded during the experiments were within the normal range and the variation between the treatments was insignificant.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Results of the present study revealed that the two sublethal concentrations of cypermethrin tested in the present experiment (0.3 and 0.5 µg L−1) reduced the survival and growth of H. fossilis, and the acuteness of effects was dose dependent. Similar decrease in the survival was also observed in the Indian major carp L. rohita exposed to cypermethrin (Das and Mukherjee, 2003). Effects of cypermethrin on the growth of a fish are not well documented, although there are adequate reports to establish that cypermethrin interacts strongly with protein, which in turn can potentially reduce the growth of a fish. Treatment of cypermethrin caused reduction in the level of serum total protein and albumin in Korean rockfish Sebastes schlegeli (Jee et al., 2005), decreased protein content in liver and gill tissues of C. batrachus (Begum, 2005), reduced muscle and kidney proteins in C. batrachus (Begum, 2007), decreased total structural and soluble proteins in Cyprinus carpio (David et al., 2004) and decreased the total serum protein level in L. rohita (Das and Mukherjee, 2003). Results of the present study also indicated that the treatment of cypermethrin (0.3 and 0.5 µg L−1) significantly reduced deposition of protein in the body of H. fossilis. This was also reflected in the reduction of ANPU by the fish and growth of fish exposed to cypermethrin.

Results of the present study indicated that dietary supplement of AA could counter the ill effects of cypermethrin on the growth of H. fossilis. Several researchers demonstrated that fish fed diets low in vitamin C were more susceptible to stress caused by poor water quality. Fish fed diets containing high levels (>300 mg kg−1) of AA were found to be less affected by the toxic levels of waterborne copper (Hilton, 1989) and nitrate (Wise et al., 1988). It was revealed from the present investigation that dietary supplement of AA resulted in an increase in the tissue level of AA in the fish, which in turn rendered a better growth of the fish. Various other researchers also observed a strong correlation between the growth and tissue levels of AA in fish (Brown et al., 1998; Fournier et al., 2000; Lin and Shiau, 2005; Mishra and Mukhopadhyay, 1996). The majority of the fish are unable to synthesize AA due to the lack of l-gluconolactone oxidase, the enzyme responsible for the synthesis of AA and thus requires an exogenous source of AA in the diet (Ai et al., 2004). Therefore, a dietary supplement of AA is necessary in order to enable the fish to counter the stresses. However, the level of AA supplementation, which is capable of counteracting a stress, depends on the type of stress. Li and Lovell (1985) demonstrated that doses up to 8–10 times the normal dietary requirements were necessary to achieve increased wound repair, resistance against infections or reproductive success in fish. The present results indicated that a dietary supplement of 0.5 g kg−1 of AA (actual level of 0.23 ± 0.09 g kg−1) was not sufficient to counter the stress produced by chronic exposure of 0.3 and 0.5 µg L−1 cypermethrin. Increasing the level of dietary supplement of AA to 100 mg of AA/100 g diet (actual level 44.93 ± 12.64), the ill effects of chronic exposure of 0.3 µg L−1, 0.5 µg L−1 cypermethrin on growth of H. fossilis could be protected.

Chronic exposure of cypermethrin induced an increase in the level of AA in the kidney but a decrease in the level of AA in the liver. Ibiyo et al. (2007) also found that stress depleted the levels of AA in the liver than in the kidney in Heterobranchus longifilis. It is difficult to determine the exact mechanism of action behind the role of AA to prevent the stress of cypermethrin. Increase in the level of AA in kidney is an indication that it is involved in the mechanism of detoxification of the toxicant. AA is involved in several enzymatic processes. Dietary inclusion of AA tends to increase the rate of intermediary metabolism. AA probably helps to counteract the ill effects of cypermethrin by adjusting the rate of metabolism in the affected fish.

Limnological parameters observed in the present study were within the normal ranges required for the culture of catfish. These values were similar to limnological parameters of water used for rearing of L. rohita and treated by cypermethrin in other experiments (Adhikari et al., 2006).

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors thank the Head, Department of Zoology, University of Kalyani for providing necessary facilities for this research.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
